question: Question_08_(d)
statement:
A player begins a game of chance by placing a marker in box 2, marked
start. A die is rolled, and the marker is moved one square to the left
if a 1 or 2 is rolled and one square to the right if a 3, 4, 5, or 6 is
rolled. This process continues until the marker lands in square 1, in
which case the player wins the game, or in square 4, in which case the
player loses the game.

\textbf{(c)} Given that when the initial state $x_0$ is written in terms
of the eigenvectors, $v_i$, the coeï¬cients
$(c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4) = (0.43, 0.57, 0.28, 0.93)$, determine the
probability of winning the game. Explain your solution by writing a
expression for the long-time behaviour of the game in terms of $c_i$,
$\lambda_i$, and $v_i$.
sols:
Since $v_1$ and $v_2$ are the end states of the game (landing on the
winning and losing square, respectively), $c_1$ and $c_2$ represent the
probabilities of winning and losing, respectively. (They sum to 1,
showing that if the game goes on long enough, it will end at one of
these two states.) So the probability of winning the game is 0.43. Since
two of the $\lambda_i$ have magnitude 1 (these being $\lambda_1$ and
$\lambda_2$), the long-term behaviour of this matrix is a linear
combination of the corresponding $v_i$, with coefficients being the
corresponding $c_i$ (this depends on $x_0$ because there is more than
one $\lambda_i$ with magnitude 1). In this case, these are $c_1$, $v_1$,
$c_2$, and $v_2$. Thus the long-term behaviour of the game is
$c_1 * v_1 + c_2 * v_2$.
